Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of Visible Light Driven Photocatalytic Nanocomposites for the Reduction of CO2 to Hydrocarbon Fuel

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
Sequestering carbon dioxide by conversion into synthetic fuels can be an immensely attractive approach if the conversion process is coupled with a renewable resource such as solar energy. Photoinduced carbon dioxide reduction leading to the formation of energy rich fuels, such as conversion of CO2 to CH4 or higher hydrocarbons has not been adequately studied as compared with the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis for hydrocarbons. In this context, use of photocatalytic semi-conducting materials such as titania is promising due to the ease of photogeneration of charge carriers that facilitate surface reactions involving CO2 and water vapor. At the present time, the efficiency of such photocatalytic processes is very low.

Titanium dioxide (TiO2) is widely used in many photocatalytic, water splitting applications. However, it can only utilize the ultraviolet portion of the solar spectrum (less than 4% of the total sunlight energy), which results in low total efficiency of such catalyst in the sunlight energy utilization. Apparently, a critical challenge in using TiO2 for photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to hydrocarbon fuels such as methane, ethane or methanol has been the enhancement of CO2 conversion rates using the visible spectrum of sunlight. Low conversion rates due to the high band gap of native titania is one limitation, which gets improved by developing novel visible light activated photocatalysts having higher photo-reductive sites for the hydrocarbon fuel formation.

Under this EAGER grant, PIs will design and develop novel visible light activated photocatalysts by anion doping, encapsulation, nanoshell/core formulation, and band gap tailoring procedures. Preliminary results have shown that both anion doping and band gap tailoring of TiO2 via thermochemical and mechanochemical processes thus enhances the optical absorption characteristics in the visible light region in addition to the large active surface area.

Production of clean liquid fuel from sunlight and water will help reduce the greenhouse gas emissions and petroleum imports. Additionally, this project will also have a substantial educational impact, as it will be used to start a new area of renewable energy research training at Tuskegee University, an HBCU.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
A reactor was developed for the generation of fuels such as hydrocarbon and/or hydrogen from greenhouse gas pollutant CO2.  An inexpensive universal photo-catalytic reactor using UV-visible light source was developed for the tune–in operations (i) to produce hydrocarbon and hydrogen fuel from green house pollutant CO2 via photo reduction process, and (ii) for the decontamination of toxic chemicals in air/water, and (iii) to convert more toxic (CO) to less toxic (CO2) gases via photo-oxidation process.   The Co-PI and his students have successfully produced this proto-type reactor.

 

By using a photo-catalyst (TiO2) to breakdown toxins, organic or inorganic, using a UV light source, the sun; this photo-catalyst is very successful in harmlessly degrading a large number of toxins without the aid of harmful chemicals.  We have the photo-catalyst samples that operate in degrading toxins at the higher energy waveforms of UV and slightly under (250nm~360nm).  The successful goal of this project was to get a catalyst mixture that operates in detoxifying environments with natural sunlight. 

 

Publications and Presentations

  1. Bria Moore, Sesha Srinivasan, Combinatorial Synthesis and Characterization of Zinc Iron Oxide Nanoparticles for Biomedical Applications, (2nd Prize winner), 90th Annual Meeting of AAS, Samford University, March 21, 2013.
  2. Lamont Henderson, Sesha Srinivasan, P.C. Sharma, Solid State Hydrides for Fuel Cell Vehicles, 4th Joint Annual Research Symposium (JARS), March 15, 2013.
  3. Prakash C. Sharma, Sesha S. Srinivasan, Jeremiah F. Wilson, Nanomaterials driven energy, environmental and biomedical research, International Conference on nano-materials at U, of Western Ontario – August, 2013.
  4. Sesha S. Srinivasan, Nanomaterials driven energy, environmental and biomedical research at Tuskegee University, National Center for catalysis Research, IIT, Chennai, India, 2013.
  5. Jeremiah F. Wilson, Sammie Ely III, Bria Moore, Sesha S. Srinivasan, Prakash Sharma, Hydrogen Production Using Solar Energy, J. Undergraduate Research in Physics (JURP), (2014).
  6. Solving the Clean Water Problem, Jeremiah F. Wilson, Sammie Ely III, Bria Moore and Lamont Henderson, Sesha Srinivasan, P.C. Sharma, SPS Observer, (2014).
  7. Sesha Srinivasan, Jeremiah F. Wilson, Sammie Ely III, Prakash Sharma, Physico-chemical characteristics oil spill sediments collected from the Gulf of Mexico, Soils and Sediments Contamination – An International Journal , (2015).
  8. Leah S. Sanks, Corelation of band gap energies in visible spectrum and silicon to solar cell efficiency, AAS Annual Meeting at University of West Alabama at Livingston, 2015.
  9. Michael K  Carter (student), A. Kumar and Prakash Sharma, Applied to Europium Ions Doped in Silicate   Glass, Journal of Alabama Academy of Science Vol. 85 (No. 3-4), 160-169, 2015.
  10. Davin J. Hicks (student), P. C. Sharma, Spectroscopy of Glasses doped with rare earth ions, JAAS, Vol 87 (No. 1 & 2), 55, 2016.
  11. Optimization of Photocatalytic Air Disinfection, Salimu Kumasi, A. Kumar and P. Sharma, Department of Physics, Tuskegee University, (Annual AAS Meeting, U. South Alabama, Mobile, 2017.
  12. Salimu Kumasi, P. Sharma, and A. Kumar, Nanomaterials Driven Energy, Annual Academy of Science Meeting, University of South Alabama, Mobile, 2017.

    Conference Presentations

   1.  Annual Meeting of Senior and Junior AAS, Samford University, 2013.

   2.  AAS Annual Meeting, Auburn University, 2014.

   3.  International Summit on Electric Cars, Cocoa Beach, Florida, 2015.

   4.  Ninety-Third Joint Annual Meeting, Alabama Academy of Science at University of

        North Alabama, Florence, Feb 17-19, 2016.

   5.  DOT Meeting, Washington D.C, January 9-11, 2016.

   6.  EVTC Conference, Presentation at Tuskegee University, 2016.

   7.  Ninety-Fourth Annual Conference, University of South Alabama, Mobile,

        2017.

   8.  EVTC Conference, 2017.

   9.  Ninety-Fifth Annual Conference, Samford University, 2018.

     

    Awards and Honors

1.  S. Ely III, J. Wilson, L. Henderson, NSBP Student Travel Award to attend Quadrennial Physics Conference, Kennedy, NASA Space Center, Orlando, Ball Milling of TiO2/InVO4 Nanocomposites for the Visible Light Photocatalysis, Nov. 8-10, 2012.

2.  Faculty Performance Award for Research, Dr. PC Sharma, Tuskegee U., 2013.

3.  APS/AIP $ 2,000 Award, J. Wilson, S. Ely III, Bria Moore, Lamont Henderson, 2013.            

4.  BEST RESEARCH PAPER AWARD, certificate+ $ 150, J. Wilson, 2014.

5.   S. Ely, TU-SPS-K-12 Outreach Demonstration Program on Renewable Energy; Marsh W.  White Award, $ 300, 2014. 

6. American Institute of Physics (SPS- ∑Π∑)  $2,000,  6 UGResearch Students, 2014. 

 7.  Timothy T. Powell, awarded Alabama Alliance for Students with Disability (AASD-STEM) scholarship, 2014. 

8.  Bria Moore (UG Student), Alabama Academy of Sciences, $250, 2014.

9. Lamont Henderson, (UG Student), Alabama Academy of Sciences,  $ 250, 2014.

10.  Hicks Devin, Second Prize, Oral Presentation Contest, Alabama Academy ofScience at U. North Alabama, 2015.

 11. Kumasi Salimu, won National Award at Washington D. C., Distinguished Scholar presented by the Secretary, US Department of Transportation  plaque, certificate and $ 1,000, 2016. 

12. P. C. Sharma et. al., Carmichael Award for the best refereed published paper in Jl. of AAS, 2016, Certificate + Cash award of $ 250.                

13. Kumasi Salimu, honorable mention for poster presentation in AAS meeting 2017.

An inexpensive universal photo-catalytic reactor using UV-visible light source was developed for the tune–in operations (i) to produce hydrocarbon and hydrogen fuel from green house pollutant CO2 via photo reduction process, and (ii) for the decontamination of toxic chemicals in air/water, and (iii) to convert more toxic (CO) to less toxic (CO2) gases via photo-oxidation process. The Co-PI and his students have successfully produced this proto-type reactor. By using a photo-catalyst (TiO2) to breakdown toxins, organic or inorganic, using a UV light source, the sun; this photo-catalyst is very successful in harmlessly degrading a large number of toxins without the aid of harmful chemicals. We have the photo-catalyst samples that operate in degrading toxins at the higher energy waveforms of UV and slightly under (250nm~360nm). The successful goal of this project was to get a catalyst mixture that operates in detoxifying environments with natural sunlight.
